rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Two New England writers of children’s books : Jacob Abbott and Louisa Alcott.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In order to understand the place or Jacob Abbott and Louisa Alcott among the writers or American children's books, attention must be given to the New England background in which they moved and, more especially, to the history and place of women and children in that society. Much emphasis, probably too much, has been placed upon the unnatural childhood enforced by the Puritan way of life. In the years of colonial dependence, Calvin's theory of the persistence of the Original Sin was widely accepted in New England. According to this doctrine, children who died young, unless they were in a state of especial grace, were most certainly doomed. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Abbott, Jacob, 1803-1879.
Alcott, Louisa May, 1832-1888.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Les relations de famille dans le roman de François Mauriac.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Pendant ces cinquante dernières années, période bouleversée, s'il en fût,le concept et l'organisation de la famille a beaucoup changé. C'est un sujet qui a attiré l'attention des philosophes, des psychologues, des sociologues et surtout des romanciers. Bordeaux et Bazin, par exemple, avaient présenté le type traditionnel de la famille, et Bourget avait plaidé pour le maintien de la famille traditionnelle. Depuis la guerre, on s'est préoccupé de la famille, non plus pour savoir ce qu'elle devrait être, mais simplement comme un objet d'analyse: on veut savoir ce qu'elle est: en quoi est-elle différente de la famille du siècle dernier? quelle demeure son influence sur l'enfant, l'adolescent? que fait-elle de l'individu? quelles sont les relations des individus entre eux à l'intérieur du groupe familial? Bien des auteurs contemporains ont essayé de répondre à ces questions, d'où les oeuvres de Maurois, J Chardonne, J. de Lacretelle, Duhamel, Jean Cocteau, Julian Green, de François Mauriac pour n'en citer que quelques-uns. Mais dans ce groupe, Mauriac semble s'être consacré presqu'entièrement à ce problème de la famille. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mauriac, François, 1885-1970 -- Criticism and interpretation.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some fission products of furans and lignin.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: 1. The mechanism of conversion of furfuryl alcohol to methyl levulinate, has been studied, and a more satisfactory mechanism suggested than the one proposed by Pummerer. 2. The use of 2 ,4-dini trophenylhydrazine hydrochloride as a reagent for the study of ring opening in the furan series, has been developed. 3. Some older methods for the recovery of carbonyl compounds from their derivatives, namely distillation with aqueous sodium hydroxide (10%), or sodium carbonate (saturated), chromic acid oxidation and ozonolysis, have been applied to 2,4-dinitrophenyl hydrazones. 4. A method bas been proposed for the synthesis of derivatives of ð-methoxy-levulinaldehyde-dimethylal. 5. The assumption that ð-methoxy-levulinaldehyde-dimethylal is an intermediate in the conversion of furfuryl alcohol into methyl levulinate, as proposed by Pummerer, has been shown to be incorrect.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Le théâtre chrétien d’Henri Ghéon.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Un théâtre sur le plan chrétien est aujourd'hui une réalité en France où les dramaturges catholiques existent en grand nombre. Ce travail est une étude sur Henri Ghéon, celui qui se trouve à la tête de cette vraie renaissance du théâtre chrétien, théâtre oublié depuis quatre ou cinq siècles. Constatant qu'aucune oeuvre critique d'ensemble n'avait paru sur Ghéon, et qu'on ne pouvait trouver sur son oeuvre que quelques articles dispersés dans diverses revues, nous avons conçu le projet de faire un exposé de la production artistique de ce dramaturge contemporain. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: FRENCH DRAMA -- HISTORY AND CRITICISM
GHÉON, HENRI

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Aldermac syenite prophyry stock, Quebec.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The petrology of a complex syenite porphyry stock, occurring on the property of the Aldermac Copper Corporation, west of Noranda, Quebec, is described. The stock is a plexus of dykes of diverse, though related composition, belonging to a soda-rich, alkali-calcic suite. Diversity in composition of the dykes is thought to be due to differentiation at depth, antecedent to injection, rather than to differentiation in place. The economie geology of the Aldermac mine is not discussed although the ore-bodies, which occur to the south of the stock, are possibly genetically related to it.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A quantitative study of glucuronic acid excretion.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Since the discovery by Wiedemann in 1876 of a peculiar acid in the urine of dogs following camphor feeding, and the subsequent identification of this acid by Schmiedeberg in 1879, much interest has centred sporadically about the nature and physiological activity of glucuronic acid. Early investigations were concerned for the greater part with the chemical nature of this substance, and with methods for its determination and quantitative estimation. Only in the last fifteen years has interest swung to the physiological significance of glucuronic acid in the animal organism. Methods for the quantitative estimation of glucuronic acid have been many and diverse, indicating that no simple and entirely satisfactory technique has yet been devised. Methods proposed have always been prolonged, tedious, and not completely accurate procedures. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Action of phenylmagnesium bromide on anthraquinones.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The action of the Grignard reagent on anthraquinones has been reported several times in the litarature but the yields in the few instances where they are stated are generally very low (Table I). Improvements in the technique of Grignard reactions, the discovery in 1929 of l,4-addition of the Grignard reagent, under "forced conditions", to an aromatic nucleus, and the increasing knowledge of polynuclear "flne-structure", that is, the position of "the double-bonds in aromatic rings, have led to a renewed interest in the reaction between Grignard reagents and polynuclear substances.(53.86) The introduction is intended to review some of the methods and results of fine structure determinations and to show the significance of ascertaining whether or not any 1,4-addition of Grignard reagents occurs in the anthraquinone series; a more complete list of the methods of determining finestructure is given in the introduction of Part II. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The geology of the north shore of the Gaspé Bay, Quebec.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The section which has served as a type for the Lower and Middle Devonian beds of eastern Gaspe was first worked out by Logan in 1863, and later elaborated by Clarke. The former gathered much of his data from the Gaspe Bay region, especially from the exposures on the Fori1lon. The latter also studied the rocks of the Forillon intensively, and, using Logan's work as a basis, worked out in great detail the section of the limestones, both lithologically and paleontologically. It might have been expected that the section thus developed would serve for much or all of the Gaspe Peninsula. However, research during the last decade upon Devonian rocks immediately to the west has shown that there are wide variations in the lithology and thickness of the subdivisions of the Devonian rocks in the greater Gaspe region, and it has been obvious for several years, that a revaluation of Logan's and Clarke's sections must be made before the stratigraphy of neigbouring parts of Gaspe could be elucidated. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Byron: a study of his political theories.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Although Byron's popularity has been growing in recent years, his writings have a greater significance than has usually been attributed to them. A study of the biographies and articles written about him shows that ihe importance of Byron's influence on the political thought of the nineteenth century has been seriously neglected. It is my aim, in the following chapters, to discuss the political theories which Byron held and to estimate the influence they had on Europe. To present a proper background, it has been necessary to paint a sketchy account of eighteenth-century Europe and a slightly more detailed one of Europe between the outbreak of the French Revolution and Byron's departure for Italy in 1816. In doing this, not only have the historical events been given, but those ideas which were formulating in the minds of the English witers, philosophers, and politicians of the Revolutionary period have also been incorporated. The main body of this study, however, is concerned with the political beliefs of Byron, and here I have turned almost exclusively to the pages of Byron's poetry and letters. As so many other people have done, I have been content, as far as it was possible, to let Byron speak for himself.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Reactions of tetrahydrolinalool.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Considerable work has been done on the halogenation of optically active secondary carbinols. Pickard and Kenyon have prepared a number of optically active secondary halides trom the corresponding carbinols. They used hydrogen halides as the halogenating agents and in every case tested the conversion was found to be accompanied by a change in sign of rotation. They produced evidence that a Walden inversion was associated with this change of sign of rotation. They also believed that no racemization had occurred. In a later paper they reported the regeneration of an optically active secondary carbinol trom the halide by hydrolysis. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The structure of lignin.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A hithertofore unknown aldehyde has been isolated from the ethanolysis products of maple wood as a pure crystalline compound. The structure of this new compound has been completely elucidated from an investigation of its properties and derivatives. The isolation and identification of this aldehyde has thrown new light upon the structure of lignin and the mechanism of the synthesis of plant pigments. A new method has been developed for the complete, chemical separation of the syringyl and guaiacyl components found in the aldebydic fraction from the ethanolysis products of maple wood.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Theories of money, value and trade fluctuations suggested by Canadian monetary and banking history.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Some two hundred years ago there was devised in Nova Scotia a monetary system called "Halifax currency". Halifax currency was based upon certain root ideas which have governed the subsequent monetary and banking practice in Canada. These ideas in fact illustrate the essential meanings of money, credit and value in the world today. By reference to them questions relating to the reform of money and of banking acquire a special significance. When Port Royal was captured (1710) and Nova scotia ceded to Great Britain (1713) the garrison stationed there obtained its military supplies from New England by discounting sterling bills in Boston. In this way the money of New England became familiar to the first British inhabitants of Nova Scotia. The principal coins in circulation in New England were not English coins, but a hodge-podge of Spanish, Mexican and Peruvian silver, the most important of which was the "Spanish dollar", - a coin which was in almost universal circulation throughout the western world. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: MONEY
CREDIT
VALUE
Banks and banking -- Canada.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The price of gold since 1931.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Any reader of elementary economics knows that money is defined as being a medium of exchange. In the course of world history, some periods can be found when the whole economy was conducted along barter lines, that being when goods are directly exchanged against other goods. But this system was found to be highly inconvenient, and the difficulty of measuring how many sheep were worth a cow, or how many pigs were worth a horse, often proved to be insuperable. The result was naturally that trade was harmed to a great extent. Eventually some particular form of goods which happened to be universally in demand came to be regarded as a standard of value and a medium of exchange. At first this medium of exchange differed from one country to another, and it may have been sea-shells, slaves, leather, cattle or any other object which was much appreciated. But it was found in due course that to be able to fulfil its role as a medium of exchange the object chosen should have some specific qualities, it should have a stable value, it should be homogeneous, easily divisible into parts, unalterable and should be easy to manipulate. The ideal was to find some object which had a high value and a small volume. Gold and silver, and to a lesser degree some other metals, appeared to have all these qualities, and as such they gradually came to be looked upon as the standard mediums of exchange. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: GOLD (FINANCE)

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The newsprint industry in Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Because of its abundant forest resources, accessible power sites, growing population and availability of investment funds, Canada leads in the output of pulp and paper. The pulp and paper industry has headed the lists in net value of production, one of the best indicators of the relative importance of a manufacturing industry since 1920, and in wage and salary distribution since 1922. It employs 16.2 per cent of all gainfully employed in Canada as compared to mining's 9 per cent. It was first in gross value of production from 1925, when it replaced the flour mills, until 1935 when it was overtaken by the non-ferrous metal smelting and refining group. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Newsprint industry -- Canada.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An investigation of certain storage disorders of celery.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The production of celery in Quebec is, at the present time, not well enough developed to supply the market demands in the province. This state of affairs is not due to soil or climatic conditions. There is sufficient area of muck soil, favourably located in this province, to produce enough celery for local demands and the climate is suitable for celery growing. The cause of this state of affairs is that Quebec celery growers have suffered serious losses in the storing and marketing of their crops. For this reason, celery production is comparatively undeveloped, and the great muck soil wealth of the province has not bean turned to celery growing. In Quebec, the same as in other celery producing areas, the storage life of celery varies from year to year depending to a certain extent on climatic and cultural conditions during growth. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Plant Pathology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The ozonization and structure of lignin in relation to solubility in bisulphite solutions.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Isolated lignins, obtained by extraction with formic and acetic acids, which are normally insoluble in aqueous bisulphite solution, have been shown to yield water-soluble lignin sulphonic acids after a prior treatment of the lignin with ozone. The alkaline cleavage of these lignin sulphonic acids has given rise to vanillin and acetovanillone, both of which have hitherto evaded isolation from these lignins. The use of formic acid as an ozonization solvent has been developed, and its characteristics in this capacity demonstrated by experiments on organic compounds of known structure. For the first time direct chemical evidence has been demonstrated for the presence of a carbonyl group in the solubilization of lignin by aqueous bisulphites. A study of various lignins has produced evidence to show that the carbonyl group is associated with an hydroxyl group and that the presence of both these groups is necessary for the formation of lignin sulphonic acids. A new interpretation of the process of delignification by means of aqueous bisulphite solution has been postulated in view of these new experimental findings.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Cerebral ischaemia and its relation to epilepsy.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: During many years a number of observers have presented evidence suggesting that cerebral ischaemia, resulting from local vascular spasm, or from suddenly diminished blood supply to the brain as a whole, may be instrumental in producing an epileptic seizure. Investigators have also demonstrated that an epileptic discharge may originate in an area of cortex which has been pathologically altered by a previous ischaemia. In the investigation described here these two aspects of the problem of epilepsy have been studied. The first part of the thesis deals with vasospasms and focal cerebral ischaemia produced by mechanical and electrical stimulation of pial and cerebral arterial vessels. In the second part of the thesis is described the histological changes in the cortex and meninges resulting from the above type of stimulation and also the changes following exposure of the brain under different conditions. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The recovery of sodium sulphite cooking liquor.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In the investigation of this problem the major part of the time was spent in the construction, erection and adaptation of the required equipment to incineration of waste liquor. A great deal of space could be filled describing the various mechanical difficulties encountered; for example, considerable time was spent in attempting to adapt a belt and pulley auxiliary drive mechanism to rotate the furnace. This was eventually scrapped and a chain and sprocket drive used. It is deemed advisable, however, to omit such descriptive details from this treatise, as they would be uninteresting and of minor value to future readers. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Three women autobiographers of the English Civil War period : Mrs. Lucy Hutchinson, Lady Ann Fanshawe, and Margaret, Duchess of Newcastle.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In 1620 Sir Allen Apsley was Lieutenant of the Tower of London. Observant tourists passing the lodgings of the Lieutenant early in February of that year might have seen signs of unusual bustling and excitement, for a girl-child had been born to the Lieutenant's wife on January 29th. She was christened Lucy, and was destined to have her name live through the centuries as one of the heroines of the English Civil War. As three boys had been born before Lucy, a girl was welcomed with particular warmth. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Newcastle, Margaret Cavendish, Duchess of, 1624?-1674.
Fanshawe, Anne Harrison, Lady, 1625-1680.
Hutchinson, Lucy Apsley, b. 1620.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Geology of the Amm gold mine, Cadillac township, Quebec.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The property of Amm Gold Mines Limited comprises a group of seven claims in Cadillac Township, Abitibi County, Quebec. The group occupies a position near the north-south centreline of Cadillac Township between the Noranda-Valdor high-way and the Noranda-Valdor branch of the Canadian National Railways. The claims are numbered A-584, A-585 and A-5882l to A-58825 inclusive, and have a combined area or about 370 acres. The property 1s bounded on the east and north by Pandora Cadillac, on the west by Pandora Cadillac, Wood Cadillac, Routhier Cadillac and Benard Cadillac, while the railway right-of-way passes within 150 feet of the most southerly point of the property. The transmission lines of the Northern Quebec Power Co. pass through the central part of the property. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Free radicals in organic decomposition reactions. --.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Physical chemistry may be thought of as the physics of chemistry. Thus it includes the study of the physical properties of matter in its various forms, and the physical aspects of the interactions of matter, namely chemical statics and kinetics, corresponding to the statics and dynamics of physics. [...] Chemical statics and kinetics have developed to a considerable degree especially in recent years. Chemical statics or thermodynamics, being more susceptible of theoretical treatment has reached a much more satisfactory state than chemical kinetics, so that by making a few measurements and calculations we can now predict the equilibrium state of a reaction. The theory of the kinetics of reaction on the other hand is not in such a satisfactory condition, and we cannot yet predict even approximately the rate of a given reaction. [...] Thus it is evident that further knowledge of the mechanism of these reactions is highly desirable, from the point of view of both the physical chemist and the organic chemist. This knowledge is important to the physical chemist because of the obvious relation of the mechanism to the kinetics of reaction, and to the organic chemist because it appears that the whole question of the stability of organic compounds is merely one of the value of the unimolecular rate constant. It was with the purpose of increasing our knowledge of this field, that the present investigations were undertaken. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry, Physical and theoretical.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The structure of dipyrroles and indole formation from pyrroles : stereochemistry of linalool. --.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: THE STRUCTUBE OF DIPYRROLES AND INDOLE FORMATION FROM PYRROLES: From the examples cited in the historical section it was seen that pyrroles reacted with themselves to form dimeric addition products. [...] Pyrroles seldom form salts with acids, and methiodides are practically unknown. Since dipyrroles form salts with one equivalent of acid, at least one of the nitrogen atoms must be different, hence one of the characteristic pyrrole linkages has disappeared. [...] Hydrogen atoms undergo a tautomeric shift is pyrroles, in that the usual reagents give derivatives of either possible form, i.e. HN02 gives ß-nitroso derivatives only, even with pyrrole itself; and acylating agents usually attack the carbon alpha to the nitrogen atom. The Grignard reagent should show the presence of two active hydrogen atoms, but the use of this reagent as a method for determining structure in pyrrole series is known to be unreliable. [...] From the examples cited, it seems evident that like any substance of the type HA pyrroles should add to the conjugated system of a second reactant. When there is nothing else present for the pyrrole to combine with, it should add to itself for it contains the necessary conjugated system. Since pyrroles can be kept unchanged for long periods of time, this tendency cannot be very great. [...] STEREOCHEMISTRY OF LINALOOL: For a long time it has been known that optically active straight chain secondary alcohols can be converted into optically active secondary halides. [...] More recently however Hughes, Ingold, and Masterman (3) have prepared halides of straight chain aliphatic secondary carbinols such as methylhexylcarbinol under a variety of conditions such as saturation with the dry gaseous hydrogen halides and treatment with thionyl halides. They found that there was always some racemization, for the activity of their halides varied with the method of conversion. The amounts of racemization varied from 50% to as little as 3%. [...] In order to avoid this complex type so bound up with possible free radical formation, an investigation was made of the simple optically active tertiary alcohols. As there were no methods for resolving them, natural substances had to be considered. Linalool seemed to be well adapted to this work as it was readily available in an optically active form and could be reduced to the simplest type of optically active tertiary-carbinol possible [...] l-linalool was first reduced to a saturated compound before conversion into its halide derivative. Complete reduction was possible in glacial acetic acid using Adams platinum catalyst. Several other methods were tried, but this was the only one which gave the desired result. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the relative ability of steers and rabbits to digest pasture herbage.--.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Animal Nutrition and Breeding
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The limitations of routine chemical analysis and the impracticability of digestion trials with large animals as indices of nutritive value of pasture grass are discussed. In view of this situation the use of rabbits as pilot animals for farm ruminants is suggested. A trial, comparing the digestive powers of steers and rabbits on pasture grass, is reported. The results show that in general rabbits do not digest the grass to the same extent as steers, the greatest difference showing in the crude fibre fraction. Nevertheless because of their uniform response in digestibility of pasture herbage and the ease with which they can be handled and fed in relatively large numbers, rabbits have certain merits which would justify their use as pilots for steers in nutritional studies of pasture herbage.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Rabbits -- Feeding and feeds.
Grasses.
Beef cattle -- Feeding and feeds.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Biologie de Carpocapsa Pomonella L. en relation avec la temperature et l’humidite. --.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: De tous les insectes d'importance économique qui s'attaquent au verger, la Pyrale des pommes (Carpocapsa pomonella L.) est probablement celui qui a fait couler le plus d'encre de la part des entomologistes intéressés, tant de la fin du siècle dernier que du début du siècle présent. [...] Il devient donc évident qu'il serait superflu, au début de ce travail, de présenter de nouveau cet insecte commun. D'ailleurs nous ferons plus loin une revue de son histoire et de sa distribution géographique. Les circonstances, qui ont fait germer l'idée de poursuivre le présent travail, ne nous ont jamais laissé de doute qu'il ne s'agissait pas de faire une révolution scientifique au sujet de la biologie de la Pyrale des pommes, mais de chercher à connaître par méthodes expérimentales la biologie de cet ennemi redoutable dans la Province de Québec. [...] Après une première saison de recherches au cours de l'été 1937, nous croyons avoir déjà jeté un peu de lumière sur l'évolution de cet insecte dans Québec. C'est pourquoi nous voulons faire des résultats de nos observations, l'objet principal du présent travail. Nous considérons pour notre part, qu'il sera désormais d'un intérêt scientifique de posséder des données sur la biologie et les activités de Carpocapsa pomonella L. dans Québec, bien que nous soyions convaincus que ce travail devrait être continué pendant quelques années encore. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Entomology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Lady Morgan and her circle.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Sydney Owenson (Lady Morgan) was born in Dublin on Christmas Day in the year - some say 1783, others 1785, or 1787, and she herself refused to say. "What has a woman to do with dates?" she wrote in her Autobiography. "I mean to have none of them"(l). Her father, Robert MacOwen, "Anglice Owenson", an actor and director, well-known in Dublin theatrical circles of his time, was one of the MacOwens of Connaught. Her mother was Miss Jane Hill, "pious and prudent", daughter of a respectable burgess of the ancient city of Shrewsbury(2). Sydney seems to have been a precocious child, blessed with many talents. In 1788, under the name of the "Infant Prodigy" she appeared with her actor father in Castlebar, Sligo, and Athlone theatres and, according to all accounts, she played her small part very well. The death of her mother while they were still quite young left the two little girls, Sydney and Olivia, to their father's care, and, gay, careless and improvident, though he was, Robert Owenson proved an excellent father. He placed his two daughters in a good school and went without some of the necessities of life in order that they might have the best music teachers obtainable. Sydney made excellent use of her opportunities. She practised diligently at her music, piano, vocal, and harp; she studied to make herself perfect in French and read widely in every subject, even the science of the day. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: MORGAN, SYDNEY OWENSON, LADY.
